A tale of two collectors and their love affair with sports memorabilia.

Our eyes met across a baseball field, where our 6-year-old sons, who are teammates, were taking batting practice. We exchanged awkward smiles and quick head bobs. I glanced at my wife to make sure she had not picked up any of our signs.
No words were spoken, but we knew that we would see each other later that evening, as we had on several occasions the two previous weeks.
We felt safest meeting in the dark but guilty about keeping our spouses there. We knew that it was only a matter of time before we were caught.
''Where are you going now?'' my wife said after we put our two sons to bed.
Another excuse. Another rendezvous. Another expensive, late night out on the town.
''We need milk,'' was all I heard as I walked out the door.

I drove excitedly to our secret meeting place, where passions would soon collide. A light rain began to fall as I arrived. I got out of my car and was greeted by the same devilish grin I must have been wearing on my face. We spoke briefly in the glow of our headlights, then I was handed a card. My heart thumped the way it did when I wore a younger man's cleats.
''It's Barry Bonds's rookie card,'' said Matt, my friend and fellow collector. ''After all the business you've given me, I'm throwing it in for free.''

Matt and I have been carrying on a love affair with sports memorabilia since we were children. But lately, Matt's vast collection of autographed, game-used, professionally graded, laminated and authenticated items have begun to take over his home, so he has decided to start selling off a few of his most treasured pieces.

Our wives never understood this passion. They never appreciated the sentimental and monetary value attached to such gems as a football autographed by Joe Montana, a hockey stick signed by Wayne Gretzky or a Julius Erving rookie card as mint as Dr. J's game was back in his high-flying prime.

Our wives cannot see the whole picture. They will never know the amount of determination, patience and good fortune it takes to put together a piece of baseball history like the rawhide relic in my den signed by most members of the 3,000-hit club. To our wives, all the time we spend collecting this stuff is a waste of time.
So we decided to meet and conduct our business in private.

Matt, a Yankees fan, drove his pickup that night to a parking lot adjacent to a baseball field in town. The back of his truck was stockpiled with pinstriped goodies that even a die-hard Mets fan like myself could not resist.

I spent several hours admiring dozens of items, like bats signed by Reggie Jackson and Alfonso Soriano, a baseball signed by members of the 500-home run club and a duplicate of Mickey Mantle's signed rookie contract.

I raced home late that night with the score of a lifetime: a baseball autographed by Joe DiMaggio and photos autographed by Mantle and Roger Clemens. I picked up several other balls signed by Whitey Ford, Phil Rizzuto and Hideki Matsui, and Matt was nice enough to toss in an autographed photo of Joe Torre, a Mike Schmidt bobblehead, ceramic statues of Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig, and an assorted pile of Mike Piazza cards. I even remembered to make a pit-stop at a 7-Eleven for milk.
I hoped that my wife would be asleep when I got home, but this time, she was waiting for me. She demanded I give her an explanation for staying out late, but all I gave her was the milk.
She asked if I had lipstick on my face.
''No,'' I said, as I began to walk away. ''I bought a Slurpee at 7-Eleven.''
She would not let it go.
''Where were you?'' she insisted.
Gulp.

I finally confessed -- to everything. I told her about Matt and about all those wild nights in Atlantic City hotels when I was supposed to be away on business, but was really attending card shows and memorabilia auctions. I told her about the many garage sales I had visited over the years and about all those late nights online, exchanging messages with perfect strangers while she slept.
''EBay,'' I told her, ''might have been the worst thing that ever happened to us.''

After I confessed, I apologized about spending too much time on a hobby that has become an obsession, if not an addiction. I apologized for signing her birthday card with a Sharpie, but denied buying her a pair of shoes because I needed the box to store additional baseball cards. I said I was sorry for booking our Las Vegas vacation in February without telling her that the N.B.A. All-Star Game was to be played there, and for saying that getting Shaquille O'Neal's autograph was the highlight of the trip.
I let her tee off on me for a while as I stood there doing my best bobblehead impersonation. I stopped bobbing and began to babble, and then the phone rang.
It was Matt.
''I just told my wife everything, she knows all about us,'' he said. ''It's over.''
